messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba ???
messages.msgSnippet: ... Answer to my own question: it could be the small handle on the ivory lid of a ceramic caddy.  I was thinking of the lacquer type when I wrote the above.
messages.messageBody:
> "What's the little circular hole represent if it's a natsume?"

Answer to my own question: it could be the small handle on the ivory lid of a ceramic caddy. I was thinking of the lacquer type when I wrote the above.

Still not sure that's it, though.

Jim

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba ???
messages.msgSnippet: Tom, Looks more like a tea storage jar than a natsume (tea caddy) to me.  What s the little circular hole represent if it s a natsume? Jim This is a tea jar,
messages.messageBody:
Tom,
Looks more like a tea storage jar than a natsume (tea caddy) to me. What's the little circular hole represent if it's a natsume?

Jim




This is a tea jar, stylized nonetheless but a tea jar all the same.
Essential for the tea ceremony. Because it looks like the fruit of the
Jujube (natsume), it is called a natsume...
-t

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba ???
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 11/15/2003 11:53:57 AM Central Standard Time, jggilbert@EARTHLINK.NET writes: Now that you mentioned a menpo I can t look at the thing
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 11/15/2003 11:53:57 AM Central Standard Time,
jggilbert@... writes:
Now that you mentioned a menpo I can't look at the thing without seeing a
nose. Time for me to step away from the computer...

The slab gongs I'm thinking of do have a small central perforation like that
though, which a menpo nose would not. I suppose that it could be there to
suggest the point of the nose.

Jim

gang,
not trying to throw a monkey wrench into this............ but have you all
tried to turn it up side down ?

Milt


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba ???
messages.msgSnippet: Now that you mentioned a menpo I can t look at the thing without seeing a nose.  Time for me to step away from the computer... The slab gongs I m thinking of
messages.messageBody:
Now that you mentioned a menpo I can't look at the thing without seeing a nose. Time for me to step away from the computer...

The slab gongs I'm thinking of do have a small central perforation like that though, which a menpo nose would not. I suppose that it could be there to suggest the point of the nose.

Jim



Huh,
almost disappointed to learn its a gong.

I preferred the 'nose' theory. I thought it might be
an image of the nose plate on the Japanese mempo,
since many of these were detachable.

Somewhere along the history, at least one katchushi
tsuba must have come from a noseplate hammered flat
and fashioned into a quick tsuba?

Curran


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
